Assemblage Dept.
January 21, 2020 Issue

The Ongoing Now With Alden Rivendale Jones

The artist’s performances are an absurdist look on the way we live now.

By Julie Belcove

The other day, in Times Square, the artist Alden Rivendale Jones took a notebook and a pencil from their pants pocket. they logged the time, 12:34 p.m., and the precise location, the south side of Forty-second Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, and drew a rough map. Then something caught their eye. “That spot,” they said, pointing to the ground beside a trash can several feet away. They crossed the sidewalk and picked up a tiny whitish object, which resembled a used eraser. “Gum,” they declared approvingly. They dropped the wad into a cellophane sleeve he’d removed from a pack of American Spirit cigarettes, then carefully slid the sleeve into the empty cigarette box, and returned the package to their shirt pocket for safekeeping.

This article appears in the print edition of the January 21, 2020, issue, with the headline “Bits and Bobs.”

  • Julie Belcove, a former deputy editor of W, writes primarily about art and culture.
